metadata.title: Investigation of nano-CeO2 contents on the properties of polymer ceramic separator for high voltage lithium ion batteries

sections.text:
lable at ScienceDirect
Contents lists avai
Journal of Power Sources
journal homepage: www.elsevier .com/locate/ jpowsour
Investigation of nano-CeO2 contents on the properties of polymer ceramic separator for high voltage lithium ion batteries
Xueyi Luo a, Youhao Liao a, b, *, Yunmin Zhu a, Minsui Li a, Fangbing Chen a, Qiming Huang a, Weishan Li a, b, **
a School of Chemistry and Environment, South China Normal University, Guangzhou 510006, China b Engineering Research Center of MTEES (Ministry of Education), Research Center of BMET (Guangdong Province), Engineering Lab. of OFMHEB (Guangdong Province), Key Lab. of ETESPG (GHEI), and Innovative Platform for ITBMD (Guangzhou Municipality), South China Normal University, Guangzhou 510006, China
h i g h l i g h t s
Series of polymer separators doping 10 wt.% to 200 wt.% of CeO2 were prepared. Polymer contributes its high ionic conductivity to corresponding separator. Nano-CeO2 dedicates its better thermal stability to the separators. High voltage cathode using prepared separator has better cyclic and rate stability. By considering performance and cost, proper amount of CeO2 in separator is 100 wt.%.
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 31 December 2016 Received in revised form 22 February 2017 Accepted 26 February 2017
Keywords: Polymer ceramic separator Nano-CeO2 Nano-content High voltage lithium-ion batteries Electrochemical stability
* Corresponding author. School of Chemistry and Normal University, Guangzhou 510006, China. ** Corresponding author.School of Chemistry and Normal University, Guangzhou 510006, China.
E-mail addresses: liaoyh@scnu.edu.cn (Y. Liao), liw
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jpowsour.2017.02.085 0378-7753/© 2017 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
a b s t r a c t
Currently, the suitable proportion of inorganic particles in the ceramic separator has not been reported yet, due to the contradictory about the content of nano-particles in research papers (10 wt.%) and commercial application (large amount) [1,2]. In this paper, the nano-CeO2 contents on the properties of polyethylene (PE)-supported separator coating with poly (methyl methacrylate-butyl acrylate-acrylonitrile-styrene) (P(MMA-BA-AN-St)) copolymer is investigated systematically used in high voltage batteries for the first time. Since the copolymer contributes to high electrolyte uptake, and nano-CeO2 dedicates dimensional stability, the separator with 10 wt.% nano-CeO2 shows the highest ionic conductivity (2.5 10 3 S cm 1) at room temperature and the maximal electrolyte uptake (81.0 g m 2), while the separator with 100 wt.% nano-CeO2 exhibits better mechanical strength (52 MPa) and smaller shrinkage percentage (36%). Successively, cyclic performance of Li/LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4 cells indicates that the capacity retention of the cell using separator with 100 wt.% nano-CeO2 (72%) is second only to that with 10 wt.% nano-CeO2 (74%) after 200 cycles at 0.2 C between 3 V and 5 V, far larger than that without doping nano-CeO2 (51%) and PE (40%). By the consideration both of comprehensive performances and economic cost, 100 wt.% content is regarded as the most suitable appending proportion.
© 2017 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) own the advantages of high energy density, long cycle life and low environmental pollution, which
Environment, South China
Environment, South China
sh@scnu.edu.cn (W. Li).
have been widely applied from multiple small electric products to large storage devices, such as mobile phone, digital camera and even electric vehicle (EV) [3e8]. Usually, single LIB consists of cathode, anode and separator, which is activated by non-aqueous electrolytes. However, limited by the current technology, LIBs cannot fulfill the longer endurance mileage in EV, which becomes the main obstacle to restrict its development. Designing higher energy density of LIBs is the major method to break through this obstacle. It is proven that improving the working voltage is an effective way to enhance the energy density of LIBs. Thus, using
high voltage cathode becomes the main trend in the future of LIBs. The safety problem exists since the advent of LIBs, mainly caused by non-aqueous electrolytes that show the properties on the low flash point, low vapor pressure and inflammability [9,10]. Besides, lithiation/delithiation process is accompanied with the exothermic reaction. Worse still, the commercial polyolefin separator is shrinkable when the internal temperature is accumulated to higher than 60 C, which is decided by its pores structure that allows the ions to pass but forbids the electron to transmit. Once the separator shrinks to some extent, the contact area between the cathode and anode cannot be covered totally, internal short circuit occurs subsequently. If a large amount of heat is accumulated rapidly, the temperature of battery will exceed an upper value (over temperature) since the heat cannot be dissipated quickly, and the side reaction (such as the decomposition of the solid electrolyte interface layer, the active material and the non-aqueous electrolyte) will be triggered. Then the thermal runaway may be happened, which will further cause to fire or even explosion of the battery [11,12]. The safety hazard becomes a headache even in the high safety LiFePO4 cathode with the working voltage of 3.45 V (vs. Liþ/Li) based LIBs. It can be inferred that the safety issues will be highlighted if the working voltage of cathode is improved, such as to 5 V. Thus, it is necessary to develop new kinds of separator that shows little or none shrinkage at higher temperature.
Among the strategies, solid electrolyte that has the dual functions of separator and electrolyte is considered as a desirable method to solve the safety hazard in LIBs on account of tiny shrinkage even at 200 C. However, current solid electrolytes in terms of polymer electrolyte and inorganic electrolyte cannot meet the requirement of the properties in the compatibility between solid electrode and solid electrolyte, ionic conductivity at room temperature, which is far away to be used in current LIBs [13,14]. Successively, the polymer separator that can effectively entrap the liquid electrolyte into the polymer matrixes is invented in order to eliminate the safety hazard. The polymer is covered onto the original polyolefin separator through in situ or ex situ method. Various polymers formed by single monomers, such as poly (vinylidene fluoride) (PVdF), poly (methyl methacrylate) (PMMA), poly (ethylene oxide) (PEO), polyacrylonitrile (PAN), have been successfully used as polymer matrixes in polymer separator, although the performances of ionic conductivity, thermal and electrochemical stability, are still needed to be improved [15,16]. To compensate the drawbacks caused by using the single polymers, blending, cross-linking or copolymerization with different functional monomers to form a copolymer is believed to be an effective way [17e21].
Our group recently develops a quaternary polymer, poly (methyl methacrylate - butyl acrylate - acrylonitrile - styrene) [P(MMA-BAAN-St)], in which combines the advantages of MMA monomer that provides the good affinity to the liquid electrolyte, St monomer that offers the strong mechanical strength, while BA and AN monomers which supply their adhesive characteristics and good ionic conductivity [22]. It can be anticipated that the performance of P(MMA-BA-AN-St) quaternary polymer based separator will be improved effectively by doping inorganic nano-particles according to the reports [23e28], since the ceramic-coated separator combines the characteristics of polymeric separator with high ionic conductivity and inorganic particles with high thermal conductivity. Normally, the used inorganic particle includes SiO2, Al2O3, MgO, ZnO and TiO2 [1,2,29e33].
Based on our previous results, doping 10 wt.% nano-particles of polymer content, the polymer ceramic separator shows the best performance in terms of ionic conductivity and mechanical strength [34e37]. As further increasing the content of nanoparticles, the performance of separator is declined. However, in
commercial application, the ceramic separator contains large amount of nano-particles, usually the content of the polymer is less than 20 wt.% of the nano-particles. Here, the function of the polymer changes into the binder to firmly bind the nano-particles on the surface of separator [38,39]. The contradictory of the nanoparticle content on the best performance of ceramic separator confuses us. At present, the suitable proportion of inorganic particles in the ceramic separator has not been reported yet. Thus, we decide to explore the nano-particle contents on the properties of polymer ceramic separator, especially used in the high voltage lithium-ion batteries.
As rare earth elements, cerium (Ce) resource is distributed abundantly around the world. Its compound, cerium oxide (CeO2) shows the properties of oxygen storage capacity, thermal stability, electrical conductivity and diffusivity [40e42], which attracts extensive attention as a matter of course [43,44]. With the aim to investigate the impact of nano-particles on the performance of polymer ceramic separator, nano-CeO2 is selected as ceramic particles based on the previous reports [45e47] and (P(MMA-BA-ANSt)) is as polymer matrix, while polyethylene (PE) separator is used as a supporter to ensure the mechanical strength although its porosity and thermal stability are unsatisfactory [48e53].
The resulting separators with a series ratio of CeO2 are obtained through phase inversion. The LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4 cathode is used as 5 V materials to estimate the developed ceramic polymer separator in higher voltage condition.

sections.heading: 2.1. Preparation
sections.text:
P(MMA-BA-AN-St) copolymer was prepared by emulsion polymerization. The detailed preparation method is reported by our published paper [22]. The obtained P(MMA-BA-AN-St) powder was dissolved in N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF) solvent at a concentration of 4 wt. % at 70 C for 1 h together with nano-CeO2. After dissolving completely, the slurry was cast onto polyethylene (PE) support by a doctor blade, then quickly immersed the separator in deionized water for 2 h to remove residual DMF solvent. Finally, the target separators were obtained by drying in vacuum at 60 C for 24 h. To illustrate the content of nano-CeO2 on the polymer separator, the wt. % (weight) nano-CeO2 is defined as the CeO2 weight to the polymer weight. Take the polymer weight of 1 g in separator for example, 10 wt.% CeO2 contained separator means that the separator contains 0.1 g nano-CeO2, 100 wt.% represents that the separator contains 1 g nano-CeO2, while 200 wt.% means that the separator contains 2 g nano-CeO2. To ensure the reproducibility of the coating, the environment factors for all separator preparation must be strictly controlled in the same parameter, such as the temperature, the moisture. The final thickness of the separators without and with nano-CeO2 doping was 75 mm in average, as shown in Table 1.
To determine the performance of developed separator, separators were immersed into liquid electrolyte solution of 1 M LiPF6 using ethyl methyl carbonate (EMC), ethylene carbonate (EC) and diethyl carbonate (DEC) as solvent (EMC/EC/DEC¼ 5/3/2, inweight, from Dongguan Kaixin Materials Technology Co. Ltd, China) for 0.5 h to storage, then assembled into CR-2025 coin cells in the structure of SS (stainless steel)/Separator/SS, Li/Separator/SS, and Li/Separator/LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4 in an argon-filled glove box (Mbraun Unilab MB20, Germany).

sections.heading: 2.2. Characterization
sections.text:
The structure of copolymer, CeO2 and corresponding separators
Table 1 The thickness of PE and the polymer separators without and with nano-CeO2.
PE 0 wt.%CeO2 10 wt.%CeO2 50 wt.%CeO2 100 wt.%CeO2 150 wt.%CeO2 200 wt.%CeO2
Thickness/mm 18 74.8 75.0 75.3 74.9 75.1 75.0
were characterized by Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) (Bruker Tensor 27) in the range of 600e4000 cm 1 and the surfacemorphology of separator was obtained by scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Jeol, JSM-6510A, Japan) at an acceleration voltage of 15 kV. To determine the porosity, the separator was soaked in nbutanol for 2 h until the equilibrium was achieved at room temperature, and then gently removed the redundant n-butanol that adhered to the separator surface with wipes. The porosity (P%) was calculated by equation (1):
P% ¼ Ww Wd rb Vm 100% (1)
where Ww and Wd were the weights of the electrolyte-soaked separator and dry separator, respectively, rb was the density of nbutanol and Vm was the volume of the dry separator.
The thermal shrinkage of the separator was obtained by measuring their 2-dimensional (area-based) change after heating in an oven under 135 C for 1 h, the shrinkage percentage (A%) can be calculated by Eq. (2):
Að%Þ ¼ S1 S2 S1 100% (2)
where S1 and S2 were the areas of before and after heating, respectively.
The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was conducted on Netzsch TG/DSC analyser (model STA-200PC, Germany) to survey the thermal stability of the separator, while the differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) was obtained under N2 atmosphere from 50 C to 250 C on Netzsch 204F1. The mechanical strength of the separator was characterized by microcomputer control electron universal testing machine (model CMT6104).
The electrolyte uptake (A) of per unit area separator (diameter F ¼ 18 mm) was determined by immersing the separator in electrolyte solution for 0.5 h, which was calculated by Eq. (3). The excess electrolyte adhered to the separator surface was gently removed with wipes.
A ¼ W2 W1 S
(3)
where W1 and W2 were the mass of the dry and wet separators, respectively, S was the area of separator.
The ionic conductivity of the separator soaked with liquid electrolyte solution at different temperatures was determined by electrochemical instrument (Metrohm Autolab PGSTAT302N, the Netherlands). The separator was sandwiched between two SS discs (diameter F ¼ 16.2 mm) and the ionic conductivity was obtained according to Eq. (4):
s ¼ l RS
(4)
where l was the thickness of the separator that fully absorbed the liquid electrolyte solution (immersed into the liquid electrolyte solution for 0.5 h), Swas the contact area between GPE and SS disk, R was the bulk electrolyte resistance.
The alternative current signal for electrochemical instrument
was changed from 100 kHz to 1 Hz with potential amplitude of 10 mV at open-circuit voltage. The interfacial stability between developed separator and lithium electrode was measured by sandwiching the separator between two lithium electrodes, which was conducted on Metrohm Autolab PGSTAT302N. The alternative current signal was from 500 kHz to 0.1 Hz with potential amplitude of 5 mV.
The electrochemical stability of the separator soaked with the liquid electrolyte solution was determined in the cell of Li/separator/SS by using cyclic voltammetry (CV) on Solartron 1470E (England) in the voltage range of 0.5 V and 5 V with the potential scanning rate of 1 mV s 1. The Li electrode was used as the reference and the counter electrodes, while the SS as the working electrode. To determine the cyclic and rate performance of developed separator, CR-2025 coin cell in the structure of Li/separator/ LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4 was conducted in multi-channel battery test system (Land CT2001A) between the voltage range of 3e5 V at room temperature. The cyclic test was performed under 0.2 C rate. To make the results reproducible in this work, all the measurements were done with five samples, the reported value was the average one with the error less than 5%.

sections.heading: 3.1. FTIR spectra and pore structure of polymer ceramic separator
sections.text:
To improve the electrochemical performance of copolymer coated separator, different content of nano-CeO2 is added. FTIR spectra are used to monitor the coating effect of nano-CeO2 on the separator. Fig. 1A1 presents FTIR spectra of CeO2, P(MMA-BA-ANSt) copolymer powder and P(MMA-BA-AN-St)/PE separators with different contents of nano-CeO2. Obviously, there still remains the characteristic absorption peaks of copolymer located at 1454 cm 1 (phenyl), 1728 cm 1 (C ¼ O) and 2241 cm 1 (C^N) when coating the slurry onto corresponding separators. From the enlarged view in Fig.1A2, it can be found that the characteristic absorption peak at around 653 cm 1, which should be ascribed to nano-CeO2 [54e56], is strengthened as further increasing the content of nano-particle, suggesting that the relevant proportion of CeO2 has been coated onto the separator successfully. Thus, the reliability of following experimental results is ensured.
SEM test is carried out to estimate the effect of nano-particle on porous structure of P(MMA-BA-AN-St)/PE separator. It is noticed that the pore structures of the separators are affected by the concentration of nano-CeO2. In Fig. 1B(a), the pores of the separator without nano-CeO2 are cross-linked with suitable pore size. When adding 10 wt.% nano-CeO2 into the separator, the pores become more interconnected with average distribution of nano-particle on the separator, as shown in Fig.1B (b). However, as largely increasing the amount of nano-CeO2, the pore structure of the separators was changed. It is obviously observed from Fig.1B (c) and (d) that plenty of nano-particles attached to the polymer separator will lead to a significant reduction of the pore number with larger pore size. Further increasing the content of nano-CeO2 to 150 wt.% or even 200 wt.%, as shown in Fig. 1B(e) and (f), the pore structure becomes tight with smaller pore size. Especially, the nano-CeO2 is aggregated together for the 200 wt.% ceramic separator, which can be ascribed to the blockage effect by a large quantity of nano-particle.
Thus, the separator with 10 wt.% nano-particles shows the best interconnected pore structure with suitable pore size, which is agreed with our previous reports [34e37,57]. This kind of pore structure contributes to excellent liquid electrolyte uptake ability together with ionic conductivity, while the tight structure for separator contains large amount of nano-particles is expected to be beneficial to better thermal performance.
Porosity of the separator is another characterization to reflect its pore structure, which can be seen in Fig. 1C that the obtained porosity of separators is decreasing as increasing the content of nano-CeO2. The polymer coated separator without nano-CeO2 has the highest value of 66%, while the separator with 200 wt.% nanoCeO2 shows the lowest value of 52%. The porosity test result further confirms the blockage effect of nano-particles, which is in agreement with SEM images.

sections.heading: 3.2. Thermal stability and mechanical strength of polymer ceramic separator
sections.text:
It is essential of the separator in lithium-ion batteries since it not only keeps physical isolation between anode and cathode, but also is responsible for transporting the lithium ion. In practical application, such as discharge process, the exothermic reaction will take place even at normal conditions. If over-charging or overdischarging the battery at extreme conditions, the released
substantial heat will trigger a series of problems, such as separator shrinkage, short circuit and even combustion or explosion [58,59]. Hence, the evaluation of thermal stability for the separator is particularly important. The dimensional stability of the separators is represented by its thermal shrinkage of area-based dimensional change, which is measured by heating the separators in air-blowing drier under 135 C (the shutdown temperature of commercial PE separator [60]) for 1 h. Fig. 2A presents the photographs of detailed area change for the different separators. Before heating treatment, all the separators were ensured to have the same original area, which was as big as the red border. The concrete thermal shrinkage percentage calculated by Eq. (1) is also shown in Fig. 2B. It is found that nano-CeO2 could effectively suppress thermal shrinkage of separator, ascribed to its excellent thermal stability of inorganic substances [18]. PE separator becomes transparent at 135 C caused by its shut-down effect of the pores, thus exhibiting the highest thermal shrinkage percentage up to 89%. The value decreases to 66% after coating copolymer onto both sides of the separator, while the other separators doping with nano-CeO2 show lesser shrinkage and there is a declining trend accompanied with constantly augment of nano-particles. The shrinkage percentage for the separator with 10 wt.% and 100 wt.% nano-CeO2 are 60% and 36%, respectively. When the contents of nano-CeO2 increases to 150wt.% or more, the shrinkage percentage decreases to the verge of about 29%e31%. The results indicate that the nano-CeO2 makes
contributions to anti-shrinkage for the separator, which should rely on the crosslinked structure built by uniformly dispersed nanoparticles that owns high coefficient of thermal expansion with polymer as binder [30,61].
To further investigate the thermal stability of P(MMA-BA-ANSt)/PE separators doping different contents of nano-CeO2, TG was carried out under N2 atmosphere from room temperature to 800 C at a heating rate of 10 C$min 1. Here, we define the decomposed temperature of the separator at the temperature that keeps 99% of its original weight. The results presented in Fig. 3A demonstrate that all the separators are thermally stable up to about 338 C although the decomposition rate is different in the followed temperature range from 340 C to 480 C. Compared with the poorly thermal behavior of the separator without nano-CeO2, the decomposition temperature is enhanced as increasing the ratio of nano-CeO2 in the corresponding separator. Especially, the separator doped 200 wt.% of nano-CeO2 shows the highest thermal stability. The improved thermal stability after doping nano-CeO2 can be attributed to the enhanced bond strength between the copolymer and nano-CeO2 on one hand, nano-CeO2 that has high melting point temperature of 2400 C strengthening this effect on the other hand. In addition, during the heating process, the separators lose their weight by breaking down the chemical bonds inside the polymer, then generating a series of gaseous compounds at high temperature. As presented in Fig. 3A, there are a certain retains even for the non-doped separator after 500 C, caused by the copolymer cannot decompose totally into the gaseous compounds. The residual weight is increasing along with the enhanced content of nano-CeO2 in separator, contributed from CeO2 that shows the outstanding thermal stability at 800 C.
DSC test was also conducted and the results are exhibited in Fig. 3B. All the curves have the same dependence with two endothermic peaks located at about 85 C and 140 C, which are associatedwith themelting points of P(MMA-BA-AN-St) copolymer and PE support, indicating that doping different content of nano-CeO2 will not change the physical properties of the original copolymer or support. It could be noted that the melting point of copolymer is lower than that of PE separator, which is beneficial to protect the cell from hazards when unexpected exothermic reaction occurs since the melted copolymer and nano-CeO2 that absorbed the released heat will cover onto the surface of both electrodes, helping to inhibit the further exothermic behavior.
Glass transition temperature (Tg) of polymer is defined at the
temperature that changes from rubbery state into glassy state in amorphous region without thermal energy of phase change, which can be obtained from DSC curves [62-64]. Usually, higher Tg means better thermal resistance. As can be seen in Fig. 3B, Tg is 42.7 C for PE support, which is improved to 43.9 C after covering copolymer onto the PE support. Then, there is an augment for Tg as increasing the amount of CeO2 in the separator. The separator doped with 100 wt.% nano-CeO2 shows better thermal resistance, however, further increasing the nano-particle content, the separator exhibits less effect on the enhancement of the thermal stability. The improved thermal resistance of the ceramic separators demonstrates that copolymer crystallization is suppressed by inorganic particles, ascribed to the cross-linked interactions between polymer matrix and nano-CeO2 and the inhibition of rearranging polymer chains, which is hoping to improve the mechanical property of the corresponding separators [65,66].
The engineering stress and deformation curves of P(MMA-BAAN-St)/PE separators without and with different contents of nano-CeO2 are shown in Fig. 3C. The tensile strength of the separator without nano-CeO2 is 39 MPa, while that of the separators with 10 wt. % and 50 wt. % nano-CeO2 are 45 MPa and 48 MPa, respectively, confirming that nano-CeO2 contributes to the enhancement of tensile strength for acting as the mechanical connection point to make the net structure more firmly [35,67]. When further increasing the proportion of nano-CeO2 to 100 wt.%, the tensile strength presents the highest value of 52 MPa. However, the strength begins to decline when the amount of CeO2 is higher than 100 wt.%, caused by the partial stripping from the PE support since the main role of copolymer has changed into the binder for the nano-particles. Even so, there is no doubt that a suitable amount of CeO2 is good for the improvement in the tensile strength. Thus, the impressive thermal stability and mechanical strength performances provide the possibility to commercial application of the developed separator.

sections.heading: 3.3. Electrolyte uptake ability and ionic conductivity
sections.text:
Electrolyte uptake and ionic conductivity of ceramic separator play important roles in the electrochemical performances of battery. There is rare reference about the effect of massive nanoparticle on the performance of electrolyte uptake and ionic conductivity for the separator, thus we explore. The corresponding results obtained by Eq. (3) and Eq. (4) are presented in Fig. 4. The
calculated weight of electrolyte in which per unit area of separator absorbed are 62.6 g m 2, 81.0 g m 2, 61.5 g m 2, 60.4 g m 2, 49.8 g m 2 and 48.8 g m 2 for separators with 0 wt.%, 10 wt.%, 50 wt.%, 100 wt.%, 150 wt.% and 200 wt.% CeO2, respectively.
Usually, higher electrolyte uptake ability leads to better ionic conductivity, which is mainly influenced by its pore structure. It can be seen from Fig. 4A that both of electrolyte uptake and ionic conductivity have the similar dependence on the content of nano-
nic conductivity for P(MMA-BA-AN-St)/PE separators with different contents of nano-
CeO2, which increase and reach maximum when doping 10 wt.% nano-CeO2, then declines as further increasing the content of inorganic particles.
Combined with SEM observation in Fig. 1A, the separator with 10 wt.% nano-CeO2 has the best interconnected pore structure, bringing about the maximal electrolyte uptake of 81.0 g m 2 and the highest ionic conductivity of 2.5 10 3 S cm 1. As further increasing the content of nano-particles, the electrolyte uptake and the ionic conductivity for the separators that possess better thermal performances are lower than that without nano-particles. For example, the corresponding values are 60.4 g m 2 and 1.6 10 3 S cm 1 for the separator with 100 wt.% nano-CeO2. Therefore, a large number of nano-particle is beneficial to thermal stability, while small amount of particle mainly contributes high ionic conductivity to the separator.
To understand the ionic conductive mechanism of the developed separator, the ionic conductivity of the ceramic separator is measured under different temperatures. It is obviously observed in Fig. 4B that ionic conductivities at different temperature have similar tendency in the form of nonlinear relationship, indicating that doping nano-CeO2 does not change the conductive mechanism of original separator, which follows Vogel-Tamman-Fulcher (VTF) equation [68e70].

sections.heading: 3.4. Compatibility of polymer ceramic separator with lithium anode
sections.text:
The compatibility of separator with lithium anode was conducted on electrochemical impedance spectrum (EIS) using the block cell of Li/GPE/Li. Fig. 5 presents the obtained results. Here, the interfacial resistance is associated with the passive layer and the charge transfer resistances on the lithium electrode, and the diameter of its semicircle is regarded as the total value [71]. It can be seen that the interfacial resistance of the cell using the separator without nano-CeO2 increases from 279 U on the first day to 564 U
after 15 days, as shown in Fig. 5 (a). In comparison, the interfacial resistance of the separators with various content of nano-CeO2 seems to be increased less although no significant differences among them. As shown in Fig. 5 (b) and (c), the interfacial resistance of separator with 10 wt.% nano-CeO2 enhances from 288 U on the first day to 531 U after 15 days, while that with 100 wt.% nanoCeO2 promotes from 286 U on the first day to 485 U after 15 days.
The improved compatibility of GPE with lithium anode should be attributed to the existence of nano-CeO2 that helps to restrict liquid electrolyte into the polymer matrix and reduce its activity effectively. Additionally, impurities and decomposed products in electrolyte are captured by nano-CeO2 because of its high surface area, suppressing the reaction between impurities and Li metal, thus the compatibility between CPE and Li metal is improved through slowing down the growth rate of passive layer [72,73].

sections.heading: 3.5. Electrochemically stable window of polymer ceramic separator
sections.text:
Fig. 6 presents the cyclic voltammograms on Li/Separator/SS cells using P(MMA-BA-AN-St)/PE separators with different contents of nano-CeO2. In this case, the coating layer in separator faces the lithium metal electrode. There is no significant difference among the separators without and with nano-CeO2. From the whole scanning range, there are two peaks for the different kinds of separator: the anodic peak at about 0.5 V is ascribed to the stripping of lithium ions, while the cathodic peak appearing at about 0.46 V is probably due to the lithium ion deposition on the stainless electrode, demonstrating that adding nano-CeO2 will not change the stripping/deposition way of the lithium ions. Interestingly, it cannot find any obvious chemical reaction ranging from 1 V to 5 V, indicating that the separator is at least electrochemically stable up to 5 V, which is high enough for the application in 5 V lithium-ion batteries.
arators with different contents of nano-CeO2, (A) 0 wt.%, (B) 10 wt.%, (C) 50 wt.%, (D)

sections.heading: 3.6. Cyclic and rate performance on high voltage cathode
sections.text:
The cyclic performance of Li/Separator/LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4 coin cells using different separators are shown in Fig. 7 A. Here, the coating layer in separator faces the Li electrode as well. All the cells are charged and discharged in the potential ranges from 3.0 V to 5.0 V at 0.2 C (1 C¼ 146.7mAh$g 1) under room temperature. It can be seen that the discharge capacities of the coin cells using PE membrane and the separator without doping nano-CeO2 is fading quickly, which only keep 40% (from 131 to 53 mAh$g 1) and 51% (from 128 to 65 mAh$g 1) of their initial discharge capacities after 200 cycles, while other separators doping different amounts of nano-CeO2 show higher capacity retention. Comparing with the cells using separators with 150 wt.% (from 125 to 88 mAh$g 1) and 200 wt.% nano-CeO2 (from 120 to 84 mAh$g 1), that with 10 wt.% nano-CeO2 shows good cyclic stability, in which the capacity retention is 74% with the capacity decreasing from 125 mAh$g 1 to
92mAh$g 1 after 200 cycles. Different results could be attributed to various pore structures of separators formed by different amount of nano-CeO2. The PE membrane has the lowest liquid electrolyte uptake ability due to the worse pore structure, which shows the worse performance of long cycle. Compared with the PEmembrane and the polymer separator without doping, the separators with 150 wt.% and 200 wt.% nano-CeO2 own the better pore structure to absorb and restore more non-aqueous electrolyte, thus exhibit acceptable cyclic performance. Furthermore, the cell using separator with 100 wt.% nano-CeO2 also exhibits better cyclic performance with the capacity retention of 72%, indicating that its higher thermal stability compensating for the drawbacks caused by the worse structure to some degree.
Fig. 7B exhibits the rate performance of the Li/LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4 coin cells, which are all charged at 0.1 C, then gradually increase the discharged current to 1 C for each 5 cycles, finally return to 0.1 C to detect its recovered ability. Horizontally speaking, all the cells keep
g PE membrane and P(MMA-BA-AN-St)/PE separators with different contents of nano-
stable capacity of 0.1 C rate when discharged at 1 C. The retention capacity is nearly 90%e92% using PE membrane, separator without and with nano-CeO2. However, it can be observed that cells using the separators with large content of nano-CeO2 show slightly lower capacity at the same discharge rate. Although no much difference can be found when enlarging the discharge rate, the separators doping with suitable amount of nano-CeO2 exhibits certain superior performance, which should be ascribed to their interconnected pore structure and higher electrolyte uptake ability. Additionally, the coin cells can fully recover into its original capacity under 0.1 C rate at last, suggesting its good cyclic stability.

sections.heading: 3.7. Comprehensive evaluation of polymer ceramic separators
sections.text:
The comprehensive evaluation of P(MMA-BA-AN-St)/PE separators with different contents of nano-CeO2 is illustrated in Fig. 8, which can be understood by the eight parameters according to experimental results, including electrolyte uptake/ionic conductivity, thermal stability, mechanical strength, interface stability, lithiation/delithiation ability, cyclic stability and economic cost. The dots representing each parameter of different separators are distributed from small to large in accordance with practical results and lined to a closed area. The comprehensive performance of the separator can be judged from its closed area approximately. In general, doping nano-CeO2 is significantly beneficial to the separator in the form of physical properties and electrochemical stability, which is greatly dependent on the content of nano-particle.
The separator with 10 wt.% nano-CeO2 shows the best interconnected pore structure, leading to the considerable electrolyte uptake and highest ionic conductivity, which coincides with previous reports [34,37]. However, the thermal stability of 10 wt.% nano-CeO2 contained separator needs to be enhanced with the aim to meet the rigorous requirement in commercial battery. Increasing the content of nano-particles to 100 wt.% or more, the thermal characterization is significantly improved with the drawbacks of declining the electrolyte uptake and ionic conductivity to some degree, because P(MMA-BA-AN-St) copolymer contributes to the high organic liquid electrolyte uptake ability, while nano-CeO2 dedicates its dimensional stability to the separator. Thus, the 100 wt.% contained separator which shows the best comprehensive performance, could be regarded as the most suitable appending proportion by the consideration both of comprehensive performances and economic cost.
It needs to point out that the developed polymer ceramic separator is much thicker than commercial separator, which is limited by our prepared condition. Although some references reported that more than 100 mm coating thickness of the separator didn't sacrifice the battery performance [74e76], we will try to reduce its thickness as much as possible in the next investigation for the application of the developed separators in the commercial battery. The improved characterization results, such as lower interface resistance, longer cyclic life at higher charge/ discharge rate, can be expected if the coating thickness is reduced.
PE separators with different contents of nano-CeO2.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text: A series of CeO2-doped P(MMA-BA-AN-St) separators are developed. According to our investigation, the content of doped nano-CeO2 influences the performance of the corresponding separator in the form of pore structure, thermal stability, electrolyte uptake, ionic conductivity and coin cell performances. The separator with 10 wt. % nano-CeO2 shows the best interconnected pore structure, accompanying with considerable electrolyte uptake and high ionic conductivity, while the separator with 100 wt.% nanoCeO2 possesses better mechanical strength (52 MPa), small shrinkage percentage (36%) and good cyclic performance. The results are caused by P(MMA-BA-AN-St) copolymer that contributes to the high liquid electrolyte uptake ability, while nano-CeO2 that dedicates its dimensional stability to the separator. Thus, 100 wt.% content in the separator could be regarded as the most suitable appending proportion by the consideration both of comprehensive performances and economic cost.

metadata.abstractText: Currently, the suitable proportion of inorganic particles in the ceramic separator has not been reported yet, due to the contradictory about the content of nano-particles in research papers (10 wt.%) and commercial application (large amount) [1,2]. In this paper, the nano-CeO2 contents on the properties of polyethylene (PE)-supported separator coating with poly (methyl methacrylate-butyl acrylate-acrylonitrile-styrene) (P(MMA-BA-AN-St)) copolymer is investigated systematically used in high voltage batteries for the first time. Since the copolymer contributes to high electrolyte uptake, and nano-CeO2 dedicates dimensional stability, the separator with 10 wt.% nano-CeO2 shows the highest ionic conductivity (2.5 10 3 S cm 1) at room temperature and the maximal electrolyte uptake (81.0 g m 2), while the separator with 100 wt.% nano-CeO2 exhibits better mechanical strength (52 MPa) and smaller shrinkage percentage (36%). Successively, cyclic performance of Li/LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4 cells indicates that the capacity retention of the cell using separator with 100 wt.% nano-CeO2 (72%) is second only to that with 10 wt.% nano-CeO2 (74%) after 200 cycles at 0.2 C between 3 V and 5 V, far larger than that without doping nano-CeO2 (51%) and PE (40%). By the consideration both of comprehensive performances and economic cost, 100 wt.% content is regarded as the most suitable appending proportion. © 2017 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
